Award.AwardTitle: Big data analyses reveal social, emotional, and cognitive mechanisms in communication

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Usage patterns in large-scale datasets, such as linguistic corpora collected from digital social media, can provide insights into many aspects of communication. These resources have inspired new quantitative analyses and measures, some of which originated with computer scientists, mathematicians, and physicists and others with psychologists and linguists. The technology itself is also being transformed in order to communicate the social and emotional aspects of human behavior. Innovative lines of inquiry attest to the mutual influence between technology and behavior and the transformation that ensues as the relevant disciplines come into contact.

This award will bring together a panel of psychologists, linguists and computer scientists at the 2015 meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in San Jose, CA. The theme of the meeting is "Innovations, Information, and Imaging." The panel will describe research and analytic techniques for developing new insights into how individuals convey and understand emotions in dialog, speech, and text. More broadly, the panel will discuss how linguistic and non-linguistic coordination arise across individuals and groups as they communicate using new technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A group of psychologists, linguists and computer scientists who rely on different techniques to organize, visualize and analyze large sets of data derived from communication patterns in speech or in spontaneous or composed text presented at a panel at the 2015 AAAS meeting whose theme was Innovations, Information, and Imaging. The speakers were female and male scholars at varying academic ranks with varying nationalities, In their presentations, they showcased innovative techniques to understand how linguistic and nonlinguistic coordination arises across individuals and groups as they communicate with these new technologies.

Two collaborations arose from this conference. One group of speakers has a manuscript under review to examine linguistic and nonlinguistic coordination across a constant group of speakers who intereacted by texting over a four year period. A second combination of speakers is examining collective and individualistic thinking in the context of on line texting about a crisis event. As a result of a recent visit by the PI to the home univeristy of one speaker, the group of two professors and two graduate students has two papers under review and one already published. In addition, each of the graduate students has had the opportunity to present her work at an  international meeting.
